article.headline: Democratsâ chances of Senate takeover rise, and that could affect health care, energy and financial services, analysts say
article.body: As presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Joe Bidenâs polling lead over President Donald Trump grows, analysts say Democratsâ chances of taking control of the Senate are rising as well. âWe raise our estimate of the likelihood that Democrats will win control of the Senate from 25% to 35% based on the Cook Political Report downgrade of Republican seats in MT, GA, and AK,â said analysts at Height Capital Markets in a note on Friday. The influential Cook Political Report has changed its rating for a Senate race in Montana, where Republican incumbent Steve Daines faces Democratic Gov. Steve Bullock, to âToss Upâ from âLean Republican.â It also recently has switched one of Georgiaâs Senate contests, where GOP incumbent David Perdue is running against Democratic challenger Jon Ossoff, to âLean Republicanâ from âLikely Republican,â as well as adjusted its rating for an Alaska race, where GOP incumbent Dan Sullivan faces challenger Al Gross, to âLikely Republicanâ from âSolid Republican.â Gross is running as an independent âwith the blessing of national Democrats,â according to Cookâs analysis. âMoreover, recent polling data suggests vulnerability for Republicans in AZ, CO, and IA,â the Height analysts said. GOP Sen. Martha McSally of Arizona is being challenged by Democrat Mark Kelly, while Republican Sen. Cory Gardner of Colorado is expected to face off against former Democratic Gov. Jon Hickenlooper, though Hickenlooper still must defeat rival Andrew Romanoff in a June 30 primary. In Iowa, GOP Sen. Joni Ernst is running against Democrat Theresa Greenfield. Related:This indicator shows investors are worried about a November âBlue Wave,â and Democratic corporate tax hikes The Republican-controlled Senateâs passage last Wednesday of a conservation bill was widely viewed as an effort to aid the November election prospects of Daines and Gardner, who championed the measure. The GOP holds 53 seats in the chamber, where ties are broken by the vice president. Health care XLV, +0.90% Â , energy XLE, -1.59% Â and financial services XLF, +0.11% Â are among the sector that could be affected by a Democratic-run Senate, according to Heightâs analysts. âModest drug-pricing reform (Medicare Part D) and Affordable Care Act enhancement are more likely in a Democratic Senate, but with a narrow majority, major reforms like drug-price negotiation or a public option would be difficult given infighting and the filibuster,â they said. The most affected areas in the energy sector would be ârenewable energy tax credits and oil industry tax cuts,â and in financial services, the ârisk comes from Biden nominees for regulatory bodies.â Read more:Biden unveils plan that would add a public option to Obamacare The Height teamâs views have some similarities with a take last month from analysts at Capital Alpha Partners, who said they see increasing chances for Democrats to take the White House and the Senate while maintaining control of the House of Representatives. âCapital Alpha now flips to predict 55% odds of a Democratic White House and Senate,â the analysts wrote in a May note. They said that outcome could hurt âhealth care, energy, financial, defense, and other sectors we have long labeled as âred stocks,â or better positioned under Republican control.â Related:Bidenâs lead grows to 12 points in Fox News poll And see:Bidenâs VP search is getting âoutsized attentionâ and could even shake the stock market âNewly at risk might be not only the Trump administrationâs deregulatory agenda but the 2017 tax cuts,â Capital Alphaâs team added. âPerhaps winning, however, could be âblue stocksâ in the infrastructure, clean energy, Medicaid HMO, and housing sectors.â This report was first published on June 19, 2020.
